<p>Ariel Cooper, Program Assistant, San Francisco</p>                 <p><i>India Green News is a selection of news highlights about environmental and energy issues in India</i></p> <p>March 8-15, 2015</p> <p><strong>CLIMATE CHANGE</strong></p> <p><strong><a href="http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Disasters-cost-India-10bn-per-year-UN-report/articleshow/46522526.cms">Disasters cost India $10bn per year: UN report</a></strong></p> <p>NEW DELHI: A new <a href="http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/United-Nations">United Nations</a> global assessment report on disaster risk, released last week, says India's average annual economic loss due to disasters is estimated to be $9.8 billion. This includes more than $7 billion loss on account of floods. <br /> <br /> The global assessment report (GAR) 2015, produced by the UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNISDR), has urged countries, particularly in Asia, to treat this as a wake-up call and make adequate investment in disaster risk reduction (DRR) or it will hinder their development....</p> <p>(<i>The Times of India </i>- March 11, 2015)</p> <p><strong><a href="http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/dehradun/Experts-mull-over-combating-climate-change-at-FRI/articleshow/46520358.cms">Experts mull over combating climate change at FRI</a></strong></p> <p>DEHRADUN: The summer could be six months longer; emission of carbon dioxide may double in years to come - at a seminar on Tuesday at the Forest Research Institute ( FRI) here, experts from across the world, among them members of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) mulled over strategies to deal with climate change. <br /> <br /> Discussions took off from the Fifth Assessment Report (AR5) of the IPCC, finalised in November last year. Besides the UN, the seminar was supported by the Climate Development and Knowledge Network (CDKN) that draws funds from the UK Foreign Office and the Central Himalayan Environment Association (CHEA). The Uttarakhand forest department also collaborated....</p> <p>(<i>The Times of India - </i>March 10, 2015)</p> <p><b>ENERGY</b></p> <p><a href="http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-03-09/news/59931644_1_coal-india-cil-officials-power-prices"><b>Power prices slide to Rs 1 per unit as Coal India steps up supply</b></a><b></b></p> <p>KOLKATA: <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/Power">Power</a> prices at exchanges have dipped to nearly Rs 1 per unit following <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/monopoly%20miner">monopoly miner</a> Coal India's bid to meet annual target by pushing larger volumes in the last few weeks of the financial year amid a decline in demand.</p> <p>The <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/state-run%20producer">state-run producer</a> is trying to clear supply backlog to power plants, with the result that producers have accumulated about 20 million tonne of coal, the highest in the past few years. The surplus stock has pushed prices down by about Rs 1.50 per unit over the past month.</p> <p>"Demand for power has also dipped by some 10,000 MW in the past few days mostly due to <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/Holi">Holi</a> and the weekend," said an <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/official">official</a> of Indian Energy Exchange....</p> <p>(<i>The Economic Times - </i>March 9, 2015)</p> <p><b>ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH &amp; GOVERNANCE</b></p> <p><a href="http://mobile.nytimes.com/2015/03/12/world/asia/delhi-to-delay-release-of-air-quality-data.html?referrer=&amp;_r=0"><b>Plan to Verify Delhi Pollution Data Raises Suspicions</b></a><b> </b></p> <p>NEW DELHI -- This megacity's modest effort to warn residents about unhealthy spikes in air pollution levels in real time may soon end, after a decision to first send the data to be authenticated by the central government.</p> <p>Some experts and activists immediately questioned the need for such checks, accusing the government of trying to hide -- or worse, alter -- data that shows Delhi's air to be the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/09/world/asia/cities-in-india-among-the-most-polluted-who-says.html" title="Times article">world's most toxic</a> at a time when Prime Minister Narendra Modi is pushing for greater industrialization. Recent high readings, which consistently exceed Beijing's pollution readings, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/15/world/asia/delhi-wakes-up-to-an-air-pollution-problem-it-cannot-ignore.html" title="Times article">have alarmed</a> the city's Indian elites and expatriate community....</p> <p>(<i>New York Times - </i>March 11, 2015)</p> <p><a href="http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-03-09/news/59931532_1_green-india-national-mission-afforestation"><b>Mission for Green India, MGNREGA will converge to facilitate afforestation on 10 million hectares of land</b></a><b></b></p> <p>NEW DELHI: The Centre has decided to extend its flagship rural jobs scheme to include afforestation as part of a move to create more durable assets through the programme that Prime Minister <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/Narendra%20Modi">Narendra Modi</a> recently derided as a living monument to the previous UPA government's failures and promised to overhaul.</p> <p>Officials said the National Mission for a Green India (GIM) and the <a href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/Mahatma%20Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) will now converge to facilitate afforestation on 10 million hectares of land over the next decade....</p> <p>(<i>Economic Times - </i>March 9, 2015)</p> <p><a href="http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/03/12/india-budget-energy-idINKBN0M812D20150312"><b>Modi's budget slashes environmental funding for India</b></a><b></b></p> <p>NEW DELHI (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Environmentalists in India have expressed alarm over the new budget of the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, which they say heralds substantial cuts in environmental programmes and fails to address the country's worsening pollution and vulnerability to climate change.</p> <p>The budget for the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change for the fiscal year beginning April 1 has been reduced by 25 percent, from 22.6 billion Indian rupees ($360 million) to 16.8 billion rupees ($268 million)....</p> <p>(<i>Reuters -
